= Some Theory on training =
Based on Eric Helms.
http://muscleandstrengthpyramids.com/training-videos/
Muscle and Strength Training Pyramid.

It will include discussion on strength and hypertrophy.

1) Tempo
2) Rest Periods
3) Exercice Selection
4) Progression
5) Volume Intensity Frequency
6) Adherence

Periodization is used to manage all these things.

== VIF ==
Volume           : Intensity * Reps * Frequency
Intensity (load) : Weight
Frequency        : Training per week

Increase the intensity of the program will affect the capacity to recover.
And the volume might come down. Or increase the frequency to accomodate a
higher volume program.

Specificity: To get a certain outcome in training, you need to train for it.
Strength is a skill based on the Neuronal System mainly based on the Velocity,
the Intensity and the mouvement pattern you will execute.

Less specificity is needed for hypertrophy. Experiment, 2 groups with the same
volume but different intensity, one group with 3 reps max, the other group with
10 reps max. They got the same amount of muscle growth. This show that specificity
for hypertrophy has a broad range. However, the 3 reps max group get stronger
than the 10 reps group. This means that if you want to get stronger you have to
lift heavier, but the muscle growth is based on the quality of the body.

As a result,
    - specificity for strength: developping Neuronal System and skill;
    - hypertrophy: loading the muscle on a progressive way.

In the longterme, we need to get stronger.
10 weeks training.

Hypertrophy:
Effective rep
Percentage of a one rep max, five, three rep max
RPE


== Volume ==
Total work perform.
- Skill acquisition
- Neurologic adaptation
- Hypertrophy

Fatigue management.

35 - 90 reps per week per body part (overlap included)
Depending the intensity

Conclusion: 40 to 70 reps/bodypart, for strength it will be 3/4.

== Frequency ==
Organise volume and intensity.
Each body part or mvm pattern, 2 to 3 time per week.

Consider overlap and make it moderate if necessary.

== Intensity ==
1 to 15 reps max,   for strength, 6 or lower at 3/4.
                    for hypertrophy, above 6.

== Recommendation ==
Recommendation Hypertrophy:
3/4 of volume - 6 to 12 range rep
1/4 of volume - 12 to 20 range rep

Recommendation Strengh:
3/4 - 1 to 6
1/4 - higher range


40 to 70 reps, strength 1 to 6 RM: 3/4, 7+RM 1/4, 2 or 3 times a week, per body
part.

Example Strength (40):
Mon: Bench 5*5, Overhead Press 3*6, Row 3*8-12
Tue: Squat/Deadlift 5*5, Roumainian Deadlift/Front Squat 3*6
Thu: Bench 5*3, Falt dumbel bell 4*6, Chins 3*8-12
Fri: Deadlift/Squat, Front Squats/Roumainian Deadlift 4*6

Example Hypertrophy (50-70):
Mon: Bench 4*4-6, Row 3*6-8,
    Incline dumbel, triceps, biceps, Lat. raises 3*8-12
Tue: Squat/Deadlift 4*4-6, Leg ext, Leg curl 3*8-12,
    Standing calf 4*6-8
Thu: Falt dumbel bell, Lat pull down, Row Chins 3*8-12,
    Chest Flys, Triceps, Biceps 2*12-15
Fri: Leg Press, RDL 3*8-12, Leg ext, Leg Curls, 3*12-15,
    Standing Calf 4*8-12

=== Progression ===
Example for intermediate (linear periodization):
week 1: 100 * 8 * 3
week 2: 105 * 7 * 3
week 3: 110 * 6 * 3
week 4: 100 * 6 * 2
week 5: 105 * 8 * 3

Example for intermediate Isolqtion 3*12-15 or 8-12:
week 1: 20 * 14, 13, 12
week 2: 20 * 14, 14, 12
week 3: 20 * 14, 14, 13
week 4: 20 * 12, 12
week 5: 20 * 15, 15, 14
week 6: 20 * 15, 15, 15
week 7: 25

Example for advanced on compound mouvement:
Note that with AMRAP (As Much Rep As Possible) - it is possible to derive 1RM
1RM

=== Periodization models ===
Block (Hypertrophy oriented)
Accumulation - 6 weeks: Build from 40 to 70 reps, 3x/weeks
Intensify - 4 weeks: 40 to 50 reps, 2x/weeks (Close to failure)
Realise - 1 week: 40 reps, 2x/week and 1 week 1 RM and accesories.

DUP (Strength)
on|off
Bench every session
Alternate Squat/DL
Rotate each lift through:
    6-12 nearing failure
    1-3 at 75%-85%
    1-6 1M or ARMAD
Every 4 weeks and 1 week light.

Taper (Realisation)
Allow fatigue to go down.
1-2 weeks, 33-66% of normal volume, 0-10% reduction in Intensity
can be combined with 1-3 days off

=== Tempo ===
load velocity - the load determine the load.
Extentric - less energy, controling the load, stronger
Concentric
Impulse
Force: mass * acceleration

Hypertrophy: Make sure you are in control
Strength: in control too but not that strict.

Le point faible c'est le mouvement concentric (car on est
moins fort qu'en exentric) donc le mouvement exentric sera limite par le poids
qu'on peut prendre en concentric, et donc on ne peut pas profiter du travail
exentric car le poid sera trop leger (car il y a des etudes qui montre qu'en
exentric tu as un plus gros volume car tu peux prendre plus lourd.  Mais les
etudes en laboratoire isole la partie extentric ce qui n'est pas possible en
salle ou on est oblige de lever soi meme le poid en concentric). Et en fait
ralentir le poid a pour but de simuler ce qui est fait en laboratoire pour
jouer sur le mouvement exentric mais le poid est trop leger donc ca na pas
d'interet.

Deplus, il dit aussi que l'autre argument c'est time under tension.
car il faut tenir de la magnitude car pour lui la force c'est la tension et
force = masse * acceleration (comme un sprinter) (different de power),
impulse = force * time et en fait un extentric mouvement lent va fatigue et
empecher le volume total.
